items.content_html:
This big ol’ hog, shimmering red muscle as it idles outside the Chief diner on a Sunday morning scorcher in July in Craryville, NY. No small part of me wants to blast away on it and outrun this 95 degree day.
But we get in my Honda hybrid, turn on the AC and the cruise control, and drive on down the Taconic Parkway.
items.content_text: This big ol’ hog, shimmering red muscle as it idles outside the Chief diner on a Sunday morning scorcher in July in Craryville, NY. No small part of me wants to blast away on it and outrun this 95 degree day. But we get in my Honda hybrid, turn on the AC and the cruise control, and drive on down the Taconic Parkway.

items.title: I have done better things
items.content_html:
35 years gone
she appears from nowhere in my dream
as defeated as she always was
as ancient and marked and beautiful.
She smiles unmoving when I touch her cheek.

I sit rewriting the same song
I have written for 35 years
as she comes to look
pressing her side to mine
across a dry border.

But the song is buried
the words opaque
and I will not tell her
I have done much better things.

-2010
items.content_text:
35 years gone
she appears from nowhere in my dream
as defeated as she always was
as ancient and marked and beautiful.
She smiles unmoving when I touch her cheek.

I sit rewriting the same song
I have written for 35 years
as she comes to look
pressing her side to mine
across a dry border.

But the song is buried
the words opaque
and I will not tell her
I have done much better things. -2010

items.title: at foot of Castle Hill Avenue
Agile and Gatsby
items.content_html: Two venerable traditions of American literature and IT project management may be neatly reconcilable. If F. Scott Fitzgerald had had a copy of the Agile Manifesto occupying pride of place next to the collected Shakespeare on his nightstand, his famous closing line may have been tweaked to: “ So we beat on, boats against the current, borne along ceaselessly into the unknowable. “
items.content_text:
Two venerable traditions of American literature and IT project management may be neatly reconcilable.  If F. Scott Fitzgerald had had a copy of the Agile Manifesto occupying pride of place next to the collected Shakespeare on his nightstand, his famous closing line may have been tweaked to:
“ So we beat on, boats against the current, borne along ceaselessly into the unknowable. “

items.title: Dr. Eric Cassell’s 11 books on palliative medicine
items.content_html:
Books I wanna read but may never get around to. Maybe you will…

Among Dr. Eric Cassell’s 11 books were “The Healer’s Art: A New Perspective on the Doctor-Patient Relationship” (1976; revised in 1985) and “The Nature of Suffering” (1991).

Dr. Cassell said his conversion to “the new religion of truth” in doctor-patient relationships did not come easily.

“It took me time to get the bloody words out of my mouth, ‘You are dying,’ or ‘Yes, you have cancer,’” he said. “When doctors use euphemisms, they tell the patient and themselves that they’re powerless.”

nyti.ms/3j12j56

Dr. Cassell said his conversion to “the new religion of truth” in doctor-patient relationships did not come easily.

“It took me time to get the bloody words out of my mouth, ‘You are dying,’ or ‘Yes, you have cancer,’” he said. “When doctors use euphemisms, they tell the patient and themselves that they’re powerless.”
